title: For Sale:  Attn. Grouse Hunters:  Ithaca 37 Featherweight 20 Ga. in 95% Condition!
postcontent:
This is a great opportunity to pick up a legendary grouse gun. Nothing fancy about it:  just a near-mint example of an Ithaca 37.

I own the big three of American pumpguns--the Remington Wingmaster, the Winchester Model 12, and the Ithaca 37. For sheer handling ease, pointability, reliability, and overall fit and finish, the Ithaca is the gun that I always reach for when I'm headed to the grouse tangles. It points like an extension of my arm, and no other pump gun shucks more smoothly and faster. I've never had one fail to feed, fire, or eject.

And this 37, in 20, is an extraordinarily clean featherweight in near perfect cosmetic and mechanical shape. Comes with a 28-inch barrel, choked modified. Straight-grain American black walnut is completely scratch and crack free; metal and bluing are likewise in excellent shape, with crisp roll-stamped engraving on both sides of the receiver and just the slightest hint of bluing loss evident on the sharp profiles of the bottom of the receiver and trigger guard. Ithaca embossed black plastic buttplate and gripcap. Weighs in at just slightly  over six pounds. And one of the best features is a little one that I always look for:  the screws on the receiver are untouched, so Bubba has never been inside.

Clearly, this was a gun that was carried more than shot, and apparently not carried in typical upland terrain, with no visible wear to any moving parts, and a bore that's mirror-bright.

Serial number dates it to 1976, the prime of Ithaca's production and well before labor, quality-control and bankruptcy issues began to set in in the 1980s. And, of course, this is a post-855,000 SN gun, which means it will take any 20 ga Ithaca 37 interchangeable barrel without fitting by a gunsmith and headspace adjustment. If you've been shopping pumpguns, you know The "new" Ithaca gun company is now headquartered in Ohio, and they are selling guns identical to this one--starting at $759 and going up to $839. Quite frankly, this one's every bit as good as the new ones--maybe better; I know it's lighter--and I'm offering it for about 60% of that new starting MSRP.

I have another beautiful Ithaca 37 in 20, which is why this one can go, but if I do decide to keep it, I'll probably have the choke opened up to IC and make it my dedicated grouse and woodcock gun. You could also have screw-in chokes installed; I know a couple of good local 'smiths who could do it for you. And, of course, fully interchangeable barrels for this gun show up regularly on Ebay and Gunbroker.

Ithaca 37s this nice don't come around all that often. If you have a soft spot for American pumpguns, you owe it to yourself to own an Ithaca 37--and this is one that will make you glad you paid a little more for one in exceptional, unmolested shape. Contact me today to arrange a time to see it. Also, my FFL is only 10 minutes away and will process a transfer to you for $10. 

I am firm on the price, but I will entertain face-to-face cash offers from potential buyers serious enough to actually inspect and handle this gun. Don't bother replying with an offer on a gun you've never seen; it's an insult and waste of time for both of us. Also, I have additional photos I'd be happy to send, and I can take more if you specify a particular area you'd like to see. They're all hi res, so blow them up to really get a good look at the impeccable condition of this gun.

I will entertain offers or trades, plus or minus some cash, for a vintage SxS double in 16 or 20 (Savage Fox B?); a centerfire rolling block (Ruger No. 1) or bolt gun in a deer caliber, especially a 30-40 Krag or sporterized Mauser in 7x57, 6.5x55, or 308; a Mossberg SSi-One barrel or complete gun in .270 or 308; or a .22 target rifle.

As always, thanks for looking.
